wikipedia_page.main: Wentworth Webster (16 June 1828 – 2 April 1907) was an Anglican clergyman, scholar, and collector of folk tales of the Basque Country.

response: * Wentworth Webster, collector of Basque folklore

Wentworth Webster collected a Basque version called Dragon and, on a footnote, noted the parallel to John Francis Campbell's "The Three Soldiers" and its wide diffusion.Webster, Wentworth. Basque legends. London: Griffith and Farran. 1879. pp. 106-111.

Similar to what John Adams had pointed 60 years before, John F. Bacon (Six years in Biscay..., 1838) considers the Basques living to the north of the Ebro river as free citizens, as compared to the Spanish whom he sees as "a mere flock" liable to be mistreated by their masters. For Edward B. Stephens, the Basques were fighting at once for their own sources of legitimacy, their practical freedom, for the rights of their sovereign, and their own constitutional foundations.Stephens, Edward.B. 1837 (1), p. 15 The excellence of the Basque home rule and its republican character is also highlighted by other authors, such as Wentworth Webster. A deeper insight into the Basques and their relation to the Spanish during this period is offered by Sidney Crocker and Bligh Barker (1839), stating that:

In a Basque tale collected by Wentworth Webster (The Lady Pigeon and her Comb), the destitute hero is instructed by a "Tartaro" to collect the pigeon garment of the middle maiden, instead of the youngest.Webster, Wentworth. Basque legends. London: Griffith and Farran. 1879. pp. 120–130.
*Wentworth Webster, English collector of Basque folk tales
suggested that name "Tartaro" derived from the Tartar people, just as the word "ogre" derived from "Hungarians", but Wentworth Webster agreed, though he expressed some doubt.
